Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: New 5G and internet-of-things systems for tracking and identification in shipping
Award.AbstractNarration: This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will advance new real-time tracking technologies that increase the efficiency and reduce the costs of container shipping across the world. The container shipping industry underpins the modern supply chain and represents a $1.5 B market. The proposed solution introduces 5G internet-of-things to tracking in worldwide shipping by demonstrating performance in the dirty, complex, and highly-cluttered environments of repair facilities and terminals crowded with container stacks.<br/><br/>The intellectual merit of this project will be the continued exploration of backscattered mm-wave radio frequency identification (RFIDs) for localization and communication. In addition, although hardware and standards used for standard ultra-high frequency RFID-based localization systems have benefited from decades of improvements, methods appropriate for higher-frequency methods are virtually unexplored and feature radically different challenges. This effort will advance the tag and reader hardware and software, followed by optimization of the standard for the concurrent localization and communications with mm-wave backscatter tags. Finally, the project will conduct verification and validation of the mm-RFID system's mechanical and functional performance.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase II Award 2025896, "New 5G and internet-of-things systems for tracking and identification in shipping" supported the research and development of a new wireless real-time localization system (RTLS) technology using a fundamentally different operating scheme than any commercially available offerings for indoor GPS.

In a typical RTLS system, mobile active radio trackers exchange messages with other radios with known fixed positions in their environments−anchors. First, anchors and trackers exchange a series of messages to make sure that they very precisely agree on what time it is. Once they do, the trackers send messages with known departure times to the anchors. These, subsequently, compare the reception time of these messages to their departure times and compute what are called Times of Flight (ToF). Knowing the speed of light, these ToF can be converted into distances. If three or more fixed anchors simultaneously determine their distances to a tracker, they can trilaterate its position and locate it. 

Atheraxon's Theia technology operates in a radically new fashion. Instead of trackers and anchors emitting messages toward each other, only the anchor emits an electromagnetic wave. When this wave hits the trackers, these add signatures onto it and reflect it (like a switching mirror) towards the anchor. The anchor can then analyze the signals reflected back toward it by the trackers, identify the trackers, and potentially locate them. The process that Atheraxon's anchor is involved in−sending an electromagnetic wave out and analyzing what is reflected back−has a long and glorious history, and a name: Radar.

Using the capabilities of radar, Atheraxon's anchors can not only determine the ranges to their tracker targets but also−like modern jet fighters' radars do−scan the space in front of it to determine 3D positions single-handedly. We go from a minimum of three anchors required today for such systems to one. Furthermore, because the trackers are not required to engage in time-sensitive synchronization communications with the anchors, and because they don't even need to generate signals to be emitted (instead, simply reflect), they can consume 1,000-10,000x less instant power and 5-100x less energy while being tracked.

In this NSF-supported work, we demonstrated that it was possible to mature our raw laboratory basic technology into a fully integrated and optimized suite of products capable of providing real-time indoor and outdoor localization of all types of personnel and assets with inch-level accuracy, using maintenance free (no battery changes required) trackers, with a gateway infrastructure 10-50x less dense and much less cumbersome to install than any other offering currently on the market.

It is estimated that a worldwide shortage in the GPS system would cost $1B, daily. This underlines how essential this technology has become and shows the scale of the markets that have stemmed from it. Nevertheless, indoors or at the smaller scale of outdoor facilities, GPS fails and positioning-based services all but disappear. We believe that positioning capabilities at the scale of logistics, manufacturing, and retail spaces will, in the next decades, become as essential as GPS is today and that the on-site spatial intelligence market will exceed the scale of today's GPS-enabled services'. What was missing was a technology potentially convenient and affordable enough to reach mainstream adoption: this is what we have built with the support of the NSF.
